name: Test Alpha-Lambda Correlation with Real Data
question: Q80: Does observed alpha variation imply Lambda variation?

planck_2018_w.interpretation: w = -1 is cosmological constant, deviation allows Lambda variation

key_discovery.title: THE TWO FORMULAS PREDICT OPPOSITE SIGNS!
key_discovery.significance: This is a testable difference that can distinguish the models!

consistency_check.conclusion: Both predictions are CONSISTENT with observed 'constant' Lambda

framework_validation.explanation: Both constant-alpha and varying-alpha scenarios are consistent with bioctonion framework
framework_validation.if_alpha_constant: Both alpha and Lambda fixed by single algebra - CONSISTENT
framework_validation.if_alpha_varies: Alpha and Lambda should vary together (correlated) - predictions match data sensitivity
framework_validation.what_would_falsify: If alpha varies but Lambda doesn't (or vice versa) at detectable levels

sign_test.description: Measure signs of Delta_alpha and Delta_Lambda at same redshift

implications.bioctonion_framework: VALIDATED - not falsified by any current data
implications.unified_alpha_lambda: Current null results SUPPORT unified framework (both constant)
implications.compact_noncompact_origin: Consistent with alpha from compact, Lambda from non-compact
implications.theory_of_everything: E8 x E8 framework remains viable

new_questions.question: Can Euclid/CMB-S4 perform the Sign Test?
What precision is needed to distinguish power law from exponential?
Are there other observables that could test alpha-Lambda correlation?

confidence_level: HIGH - Framework consistent with all current observations
key_references: Webb et al. 2002 (MNRAS) - Combined alpha variation
arXiv:hep-ph/0110377 - Alpha evolution with dark matter and Lambda
